metadata.title: Title: Carbon Nano-Onions as a Functional Dopant to Modify Hole Transporting Layers for Improving Stability and Performance of Planar Perovskite Solar Cells

sections.text:
Accepted Manuscript
Title: Carbon Nano-Onions as a Functional Dopant to Modify Hole Transporting Layers for Improving Stability and Performance of Planar Perovskite Solar Cells
Authors: Ding Zheng, Genjie Yang, Yifan Zheng, Pu Fan, Ran Ji, Jiang Huang, Weike Zhang, Junsheng Yu
PII: S0013-4686(17)31479-2 DOI: http://dx.doi.org/doi:10.1016/j.electacta.2017.07.061 Reference: EA 29878
To appear in: Electrochimica Acta
Received date: 5-5-2017 Revised date: 7-7-2017 Accepted date: 9-7-2017
Please cite this article as: Ding Zheng, Genjie Yang, Yifan Zheng, Pu Fan, Ran Ji, Jiang Huang, Weike Zhang, Junsheng Yu, Carbon Nano-Onions as a Functional Dopant to Modify Hole Transporting Layers for Improving Stability and Performance of Planar Perovskite Solar Cells, Electrochimica Actahttp://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.electacta.2017.07.061

The manuscript will undergo copyediting, typesetting, and review of the resulting proof before it is published in its final form. Please note that during the production process errors may be discovered which could affect the content, and all legal disclaimers that apply to the journal pertain.
Carbon Nano-Onions as a Functional Dopant to
Modify Hole Transporting Layers for Improving
Stability and Performance of Planar Perovskite
Solar Cells
Ding Zheng a, Genjie Yang a, Yifan Zheng a, Pu Fan a, Ran Ji a, Jiang Huang
a, Weike Zhangb, *, and Junsheng Yua, *
aState Key Laboratory of Electronic Thin Films and Integrated Devices, School of Optoelectronic
Information, University of Electronic Science and Technology of China (UESTC), Chengdu 610054,
P. R. China bCollege of Environmental Science and Engineering, Taiyuan University of Technology, Taiyuan, P.
R. China

numbers: +86-028-83207157/+86-028-83206123 (Chengdu 610054, P. R. China),
+86-0351-6018970/+86-0351-6018530 (Taiyuan 030024, P. R. China).
Graphical abstract

sections.heading: Research Highlights
sections.text: 1. Novel CNOs and ox-CNOs are firstly used to modified PEDOT:PSS as HTLs. 2. Conductivity, work function, surface tension of HTLs are well improved. 3. Acidity and hydrophily of PEDOT:PSS are suppressed by ox-CNOs. 4. PSC based on modified PEDOT:PSS show enhanced PCE from 11.07 % to 15.26 %. 5. PSC based on modified PEDOT:PSS exhibit dramatic improvement of stability.

sections.heading: Abstract
sections.text:
Poly (3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) polystyrene sulphonate (PEDOT:PSS) is the
most widely used hole transporting layer (HTL) in planar perovskite solar cells, which shows excellent optical, electrical properties and good compatibility with low temperature, solution and flexible processing. Nevertheless, the acidic and hygroscopic property of PEDOT:PSS restricts its film conductivity and leads to the degradation of device stability. Herein, for the first time, we introduce the unprecedentedly
zero-dimensional dopant of carbon nano-onions (CNOs) and the functionalized oxidized carbon nano-onions (ox-CNOs) to modify the PEDOT:PSS HTL. Besides the merits of high conductivity and suitable energy level, the CNOs and ox-CNOs modified PEDOT:PSS HTLs could provide a superior perovskite crystalline film with large-scale grains and orderly grain boundaries exhibiting a high surface tension with the hydrophobic property, resulting in a significant enhancement of PCE from 11.07 % to 15.26 %. Moreover, by suppressing the corrosion effect of PEDOT:PSS on ITO electrode, a dramatic improvement in the device stability has also been obtained.

sections.heading: Keywords
sections.text: Planar perovskite solar cells; Hole transporting layer; Nano carbon onion; Stability; Interfacial engineering.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
During the past few years, hybrid organic-inorganic perovskites solar cells (PSCs)
have become the hottest topic in material science due to their unparalleled properties for photovoltaic applications, such as the board light absorption in visible spectrum [1], long carrier diffusion length [2], compatibility of solution processing [3, 4], and excitingly high performance for commercialization [5, 6]. Meanwhile, the power conversion efficiency (PCE) of PSC has increased dramatically from 3.8 % to 22.1 % [7-10], which is attributed to the significant developments in both the structure design and interface optimization. Compared with the conventional mesoporous configuration based on high-temperature processed TiO2 electron transporting layer (ETL) [11, 12], PSCs with planar configuration employ many advantages such as minor hysteresis effects [13, 14], low-temperature solution processibility, [15, 16], and the potential for large-scale manufacturing using a continuous deposition technique on flexible substrates[17-19], which draws lots of attention for recent research work. Thus, in the pursuit of planar perovskite solar cell with higher PCE, the interface control of ETL and hole transporting layer (HTL) are vital to manipulate the carrier behaviors for device optimization in
planar PSCs [20-22]. Especially, the HTLs play a significant role for improving charge transportation and reducing interfacial recombination, especially in the p-i-n structure planar perovskite solar cell [23, 24].
Recently, various materials have been utilized as the HTLs, including inorganic
materials (nickel oxide (NiOx) [18, 25-27], cuprous thiocyanate (CuSCN) [28-30], cupric iodide (CuI), etc.) [31, 32], and organic materials (poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) polystyrene sulphonate (PEDOT:PSS) [16, 33], poly[(bis(4-phenyl)(2,4,6-trimethylphenyl)amine] (PTAA) [34, 35], and poly(3-hexylthiophene-2,5-diyl) (P3HT), etc.) [9, 36, 37]. Among them, PEDOT:PSS has been regarded as one of the most prevalent HTL for the planar PSCs [38, 39], since its good compatibility with low-temperature, solution and flexible manufacture [40], decent conductivity and transparency [41], as well as the immiscibility with common solvents used for perovskite layer [42]. However, the pristine PEDOT:PSS has numerous issues which will restrict the device performance. Firstly, the conductivity of PEDOT:PSS layer is not high enough for efficient charge transport [43]. Secondly, the ultralow surface tension of PEDOT:PSS HTL provides hydrophilic surface for the growing of the perovskite grains [44]. Several researches have shown that the hydrophilic surface of PEDOT:PSS HTL would result in a poor crystallinity of perovskite with small grain size. [45-47]. The last and most important, the device stability is seriously restricted by the acidic (pH  2) nature of PEDOT:PSS dispersions, in which ITO electrode will be corroded by the acidic property of PEDOT:PSS [48]. To address the issues mentioned above, an effective strategy has been explored which is to dope carbon based materials into PEDOT:PSS film to increase the conductivity and neutralizes the acidity of PEDOT:PSS simultaneously. Until now, several kinds of carbon based dopants have been investigated, which include graphene (or graphene oxide) [49-51], and carbon nanotubes [52-54].
Except for aforementioned materials, an innovative multi-shell fullerenes, named
carbon nano-onions (CNOs), has not yet been applied in PSCs so far. The CNOs offer a moderated specific surface area, which is fully accessible for ion adsorption due to an
almost perfect graphite network with a high degree of curvature [55]. Moreover, CNOs show the excellent electric conductivity, high ambient stability, easy dispersibility, and more readily functionalized [56, 57]. Compare with 2-dimensional graphene (or graphene oxide) and 1-dimensional carbon nanotubes, zero-dimensional CNOs have great compatibility to form nano-composite or as a dopant with other materials because the physicochemical and electricity properties of carbon onions is isotropy [58]. We can dope CNOs into some polymer or metal oxide without considering orientation and structure issues of it. There is an indispensable property for large-scale fabrication and chemical modification [59, 60]. Therefore, in this work, we introduce the novel unprecedented CNOs and functionalized oxidized carbon nano-onions (ox-CNOs) to dope into the PEDOT:PSS HTLs for the planar PSCs. The doped PEDOT:PSS HTLs show the improved conductivity, and better matchable energy level for efficient charge transfer. In addition, CNOs and ox-CNOs modified PEDOT:PSS surfaces exhibit the more hydrophobic property which can facilitate the crystallization of perovskite with larger grain size. As a result, a significantly enhanced PCE from 11.07 % to 14.04 % and 15.26 % are obtained in the device with PEDOT:PSS HTL doped by CNOs and ox-CNOs, respectively. Additionally, the correlative devices present robust stability in air ambient because of the reduced hydrophilicity and acidity of the modified PEDOT:PSS HTLs.

sections.heading: 1.1. Preparation of CNOs and functional ox-CNOs
sections.text:
CNOs have been synthesized by CVD using hot water vapor heat treated SSL316
mesh as catalyst and methane as the raw materials. CVD reaction was carried out in a horizontal atmosphere furnace using quartz tube as the reactor area. Firstly, the furnace has been pumped to vacuum, and then filled by N2. Secondly, the mixture of N2 and H2 with a ratio of 4:1 was introduced in to a furnace at 600 oC for the catalyst activating. Finally, CH4 filled into the quartz tube with at 800 oC for 8 h. Then, the raw CNOs have been obtained. The purification processes of CNOs are available in the Supplementary
Material. Functionalization process of CNOs into ox-CNOs: the prepared CNOs were added to 100 mL HNO3 with continuous stirring at 120 oC for 4 h. The product was filtered, washed with deionized water and ethanol, and then dried at 60 oC for several hours. The product was denoted as ox-CNOs.

sections.heading: 1.2. Device fabrication
sections.text:
The chemical structures of materials and device architecture of PSCs are shown in
Fig. 1a and 1b. The PSCs are constructed as ITO/undoped or doped PEDOT:PSS (40 nm)/perovskite (300 nm)/PC61BM (40 nm)/Bphen (2nm)/Ag (100 nm). ITO-coated glass substrates with a sheet resistance of 10 Ω/sq were consecutively cleaned in an ultrasonic bath containing detergent, acetone, deionized water, and ethanol for 15 min each step, and then dried at 80 oC for 1 hour prior to use. Then the substrates were treated with UV/ozone (PSD-UV3, 40 W, NovaScan) for 15 min. Different volume ratios of CNOs and ox-CNOs dispersions (from 0 to 25 vol. %) were added into the aqueous PEDOT:PSS solution (Heraeus, Clevios 4083). PEDOT:PSS and modified PEDOT:PSS were spin coated at 3000 rpm for 40 s, resulting in an uniform film 40 nm measured
with a Dektak 150 stylus profiler. The substrates were subsequently annealing on a hot plate in air at 130 oC for 30 min. The perovskite precursor was prepared by mixing CH3NH3I with PbI2 (Polymer Light Technology Corp.) in molar ratio 1:1 in N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF, Sigma-Aldrich) with a concentration of 1.6 molar. The perovskite precursor solution was then spun on undoped PEDOT:PSS and modified PEDOT:PSS films at 6500 rpm for 25 s, after 5 s, 400 μL of chlorobenzene (Sigma-Aldrich) was quickly dropped onto the center of the substrate; then the substrates were annealing on a 100 oC hot plate for 1 h. After that, PC61BM (Polymer Light Technology Corp.) in o-dichlorobenzene with 20mg/ml was spin coated on perovskite films at 1800 rpm for 40 s, then the substrates were annealing on a 100 oC hot plate for 1 h. Followed by depositing Bphen (Polymer Light Technology Corp.) at a rate of 2 Å/s under a pressure of 3  10−4 Pa in vacuum, and then the silver cathode at a rate of about 10 Å/s under a pressure of 3  10−3 Pa without breaking the vacuum.

sections.heading: 1.3. Characterization and measurement
sections.text:
The morphologies of the CNOs, ox-CNOs, PEDOT:PSS, and perovskite films were
characterized with atomic force microscope (AFM, Agilent, AFM-5500), scanning electronic microscope (SEM, Hitachi S4800) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEOL, JEM-3100F). The composition and crystal structure were characterized with X-ray diffraction (XRD, PANalytical X'Pert PRO). The attenuated total reflectance Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) measurements were conducted with a FTIR spectrometer (Thermo Scientific, Nicole-10). The ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy (UPS) was performed on Thermo Scientific ESCALAB 250Xi (dual source). The UPS spectra were obtained after the film surface was etched for 2 nm to minimize surface contamination. The Raman spectroscopy was collected with Confocal Raman Spectroscopy System (Acton TriVista). The sheet resistances are measured by Digital Four-probe Meter (SZ-82, Suzhou Suxun). The current density-voltage (J-V) characteristics of PSCs were measured with a simulated light source (CHF-XM35, Beijing Trusttech) with an illumination power of 100 mW/cm2. Electrical data were recorded by using a Keithley 4200 source-measure unit. External quantum efficiency
(EQE, SolarCellScan 100, Zolix) spectra were measured under the lump light passing through a monochromator, which was calibrated by a standard Si solar cell [61, 62].

sections.heading: 2.1. Fundamental properties of CNOs and ox-CNOs
sections.text:
The SEM image of CNOs particles (Fig. 2a) shows CNOs consists of small
adhesive spherical particles and the particle sizes range from 20 to 50 nm. Also, the TEM image (Fig. 2b) displays the polyhedral-like shape or almost spherical structure of CNOs. Furthermore, the concentric nano-graphene shells structure with a hollow core of the CNOs could be clearly observed in high resolution TEM image (Fig. 2c). The XRD patterns of CNOs are presented in Fig. 2d. Two peaks at 26 o and 43 o are observed, which are attributed to the (002) and (101) planes of graphite, respectively [63]. The XRD reveals that the CNOs could contain a similar property such as high conductivity with graphite but have an onion-like structure [64]. The result of Raman characterization for CNOs is presented in Fig. 2e. CNOs shows D peak (1340 cm-1) and G peak (1570 cm-1). These broad D and G peaks may be due to the shorter lifetime of phonon responsible for the scattering with defects, indicating disordered onion-like microstructural of CNOs [65]. FTIR spectra of CNOs and ox-CNOs are presented to verify their chemical structure in Fig. 2f. After functionalized CNOs into ox-CNOs, the characteristic peaks corresponding to various functional groups, including C-O (1037 cm-1), C-OH (1332 cm-1), O-H (1432 cm-1) and C=C (1637 cm-1), can be observed. Comparatively, the FTIR spectrum of CNOs only shows the C=C characteristic peaks (1637 cm-1) [66]. The notably increased hydrophilic functional groups in ox-CNOs can manifest the better dispersibility, indicating the compatibility of ox-CNOs when doped into the solution processed PEDOT:PSS HTL [67]. Also, the introducing of oxygen-containing functional groups will lead to the higher work function and lower conductivity of ox-CNOs than those of CNOs [68]. This phenomenon mainly results from the functionalization of CNOs, which breaks a portion of conjugated structure and localizes p-electrons and affects the carrier mobility and carrier concentration [69].
Fig. 2 (a) SEM image of CNOs; (b) TEM image of CNOs; (c) high resolution TEM image of CNOs; (d) XRD spectrum of CNOs; (e) Raman spectrum of CNOs; (f) FTIR spectra of CNOs and ox-CNOs.

sections.heading: 2.2. Characterization of CNOs and ox-CNOs modified PEDOT:PSS HTLs.
sections.text:
The corresponding conductivity is depicted in Fig. 3b, and the conductivity is 7.61
× 10-3 S/cm. The electrical conductivities are enhanced to 1.94  10-2, 2.18  10-2, 2.81  10-2, 3.33  10-2 and 4.04  10-2 S/cm for the CNOs doped PEDOT:PSS thin films, where the doping concentrations are 5, 10, 15, 20, and 25 vol. %, respectively. The enhanced electrical conductivity is attributed to the incorporation of highly conductive CNOs. Meanwhile, ox-CNOs doped PEDOT:PSS HTLs show a similar tendency as CNOs with an enhancement of electrical conductivity from 7.61 × 10-3 S/cm to 1.97  10-2, 2.07  10-2, 2.58  10-2, 3.29  10-2, and 3.54  10-2 S/cm, where the doping concentrations are 5, 10, 15, 20, and 25 vol. %, respectively. However, the values show a little bit lower than CNOs, which is mainly due to the lower conductivity of ox-CNOs than CNOs after functionalization. [69]
To better understand the doping effect of CNOs and ox-CNOs on the HTL
morphologies, AFM measurement was carried out (Fig. S1). According to the AFM
images, the root-mean-square (RMS) roughness of original PEDOT:PSS film is 0.85 nm. In contrast, the RMS roughness of CNOs doped PEDOT:PSS HTLs show a slightly increase to 1.58 nm. For the ox-CNOs dopant, the RMS roughness also increases the RMS from 0.85 to 1.46 nm. As well known, the increased RMS will make the rougher surface of PEDOT:PSS doped with CNOs. However, because of the better dispersibility of the ox-CNOs, the ox-CNOs doped PEDOT:PSS film exhibits a much smoother surface than the CNOs doped one, indicating that ox-CNOs had well binding with PEDOT:PSS. The rough surface of HTLs will create sharp traps, resulting in a severe surface charge carrier recombination [70]. So, the realization of an optimal doping ratio of CNOs and ox-CNOs which doping in PEDOT:PSS to balance the electrical conductivity and surface roughness is crucial for the interfacial engineering of HTLs.
To optimize the ratio of CNOs and ox-CNOs doped into PEDOT:PSS, the devices
based on various doping ratios of CNOs and ox-CNOs are obtained (Fig. 2a, Fig. S2 and Table S1, S2). Thus, the PCEs of CNOs doped devices are firstly increased from 11.07 % to 12.03, 13.06, 13.93 and 14.04 %, where the doping volume ratio of CNOs are 5, 10, 15, and 20 vol. % are 0.3 and 0.5 vol. %, respectively. Further increasing the doping volume ratio to 25 vol. %, the PCEs are decreased to 13.16 %. For the devices based on ox-CNOs doped HTLs, the PCEs increased from 11.07 % to 12.20, 13.36, 15.26, corresponding to the ox-CNOs doping volume ratio of 5, 10, and 15 vol. %, respectively. With the similar trend, when increasing the doping volume ratio to 20 and 25 vol. %, the PCEs of ox-CNOs derived devices are decreased to 14.01 and 13.05 %, respectively. The decreased PCEs of CNOs and ox-CNOs derived devices are attributed to the increased RMS when doping CNOs and ox-CNOs into PEDOT:PSS as the HTLs. As our proven results, the optimized volume ratios of CNOs and ox-CNOs doping into PEDOT:PSS HTLs to obtain the highest PCE are 20 and 15 vol. %, respectively. Therefore, for the subsequent characterization, the doping ratios of CNOs and ox-CNOs are fixed at 20 and 15 vol. %, respectively.
Transmittance spectra of PEDOT:PSS, CNOs modified PEDOT:PSS, and ox-CNOs
modified PEDOT:PSS films are shown in Fig. 3a. Compared to CNOs doped
PEDOT:PSS, the ox-CNOs modified PEDOT:PSS film presented a similar transmittance curve as the former except for an subdued absorbance intensity in the visible region from 300 to 800 nm. The images of CNOs and ox-CNOs dispersions are shown in the insert of Fig. 3a. The color change from black (CNOs) to light brown (ox-CNOs) is assigned to the a better dispersibility of ox-CNOs, indicating the existence of oxygen-containing functional groups [67]. Although the transmittance intensities in the invisible region of modified PEDOT:PSS are slightly decreased after doped with CNOs and ox-CNOs, all of the HTLs show remarkable transmittance in the UV-Vis spectrum and will not impede from the light absorption of perovskite layers.
spectra of different HTLs.
To further investigate the chemical structure of doped PEDOT:PSS films by the
CNOs and ox-CNOs, FTIR spectroscopy is studied (Fig. 4). The characteristic peaks at 1165, 1125, 1035 and 1005 cm-1 correspond to the stretching vibration of -SO3 group of the PSS, and the peak at 3700-2965cm-1 represents to the stretching vibration of -OH [71]. It can be observed that the hydrophilic -OH groups in CNOs and ox-CNOs
modified PEDOT:PSS films are removed. The removed -OH groups cause a modified surface with hydrophobic property, which affecting the morphology and crystallinity of perovskite films grown on it [45]. Furthermore, the normalized intensities of -SO3 group peaks are decreased in ox-CNOs doped PEDOT:PSS film. This phenomenon indicates that a portion of PSS chains in doped PEDOT:PSS film are removed or bind with other functional groups to cause weak acidity and corrosivity, and also increase the conductivity of the doped PEDOT:PSS film. The mechanism to cause the reduction of -SO3 and -OH groups in ox-CNOs doped PEDOT:PSS films is still unknown now, but here we would like to give a tentative explanation that an esterification is occurred between -SO3 groups of PSS and -OH groups of ox-CNOs. The detailed mechanism will be discussed in follow-up work about ox-CNOs.
The energy levels of the PEDOT:PSS HTLs modified by doping CNOs and
ox-CNOs are measured by UPS as shown Fig. 4b. The work function (WF) of pristine PEDOT:PSS is estimated to be 4.99 eV, while CNOs and ox-CNOs doped films show an increased WF of 5.20 eV and 5.34 eV, respectively. The increased WF is beneficial for charge extraction, and leads to the reduction of energy offsets at the interface between perovskite and HTLs, as displayed in Fig. 4c.
Fig. 4 (a) FTIR spectra of various HTLs; (b) UPS spectra of various HTLs; (c) Energy levels of the component materials used in the PSCs.

sections.heading: 2.3. Morphology and crystallinity of perovskite growth on CNOs and ox-CNOs
Modified PEDOT:PSS HTLs.
sections.text:
To deeply understand the perovskite film growing on the CNOs and ox-CNOs
modified PEDOT:PSS HTLs, we firstly evaluate the film wettability o by contact angle measurements (Fig. 5a). Low contact angle with 8 o of pristine PEDOT:PSS film provides a wetting surface due to a large amount of hydroxyl groups and sulfo groups in PEDOT:PSS. When doped by CNOs and ox-CNOs, the contact angles of films increase
to 47 o and 44 o, respectively. The increased contact angle is attributed to the reduction of the hydroxyl groups and sulfo groups, which is in good agreement with the result of FTIR measurement. Moreover, the presence of oxygen groups in ox-CNOs makes the contact angle of ox-CNOs doped film smaller than CNOs doped one.
The cross-section and top-view SEM images of perovskite films on these HTLs are
shown in Fig. 5b and 5c, which reveal a correlation between the substrate surface wettability and the grain morphology. The perovskite film growing on the PEDOT:PSS shows a rough cross-section morphology with a mess of interior pinholes. It can be observed that the perovskite films grown on the less hydrophilic CNOs and ox-CNOs doped PEDOT:PSS films exhibit more compact flat and close-knit grains, leading to less inter-grain spaces and cracks. In addition, the most of the perovskite grain boundaries growing on ox-CNOs doped HTLs are orderly and vertical to the substrate to reduce the grain boundary energy barrier, resulting from the smoother surface of the ox-CNOs doped HTLs [45]. In terms of the grains sizes, perovskite films growing on CNOs and ox-CNOs doped PEDOT:PSS HTLs also show grains sizes of 522.5 and 567.1 nm, respectively, which is larger than the pristine one of 196.1 nm (Fig. 5e). XRD results shown in Fig. 5d are well consistent with the improved crystallinity of perovskite films. The XRD pattern shows two main diffraction peaks at 14.4 o and 28.8 o, indicating the (110) and (220) planes for a perovskite structure [72]. These two peaks become sharper for perovskite films on modified HTLs, suggesting the larger grains and better crystallinity of perovskite film. No significant change of diffraction peak ratio was observed, indicating that there are no crystal orientation changes.
Fig. 5 (a) Contact angle of water on various HTLs; (b) Cross-section SEM, and (c) top-view SEM of perovskite films grown on various HTLs; (d) XRD patterns of perovskite films grown on various HTLs; (e) Grain size distributions of perovskite films grown on various HTLs.

sections.heading: 2.4. Device Performance of PSCs based on CNOs and ox-CNOs modified
PEDOT:PSS HTLs.
sections.text:
To further illuminate the influence of various HTLs on device performance, the
PSC devices with various HTLs are fabricated. Fig. 6a shows the J-V curves of the PSC devices using pristine PEDOT:PSS HTL and modified PEDOT:PSS HTLs based on
optimized doping ratio. And the detailed characteristics of devices including the open-circuit voltage (VOC), current density (JSC), fill factor (FF), and PCE are listed in Table 1. The device with pristine PEDOT:PSS as HTL yield the relatively low PCE , JSC, VOC and FF of 11.07 %, 17.28 mA/cm 2, 0.90 V and 71 %. The device’s JSC increased from 17.28 to 20.99 mA/cm2, VOC increased from 0.90 to 0.92 V, and the FF increased from 71 to 74 % when doping 20 vol. % CNOs into PEDOT:PSS as HTL. The device based on CNOs doped HTLs employing an increased PCE from 11.07 to 14.04 %. Similarly, PSC device based on ox-CNOs doped PEDOT:PSS HTLs with optimal doping ratio of 15 vol. % also shows an increased JSC, VOC, FF, and PCE of 21.34 mA/cm2, 0.94 V, 76.27 % and 15.26 %, leading to a champion PCE. The J-V curve of light current, dark current and corresponding performance parameters of the champion PSC device are shown in fig. 6c.
and ox-CNOs doped HTLs and larger perovskite grains allow the photogenerated carriers to propagate through the device rapidly and avoid the defects [73]. The increased VOC indicates a well charge transfer between layer and layer of the fabricated device. Well charge transfer can be attributed to the better energy-level alignment at HTL and perovskite interface. CNOs and ox-CNOs doped HTLs show a suitable energy level of -5.20 and -5.34 eV for corresponding interface, which leading to the improved VOC. Otherwise, these highly conductive modified HTLs facilitate the charge collection
and reduce charge recombination in PSCs. Also, CNOs and ox-CNOs can modified the PEDOT:PSS surface, leading to vertical perovskite grains boundary associated with large grains size to suppress charge trapping and recombination [45]. There are the key factors of the increased FF when doping CNOs and ox-CNOs into PEDOT:PSS HTLs. Obviously, PSC device based on ox-CNOs doped HTL exhibit a higher FF and VOC than device based on CNOs doped HTL, indicating that the more smooth surface of the ox-CNOs doped PEDOT:PSS HTL can facilitate the interfacial contact between the PEDOT:PSS HTL and the perovskite layer. Ultimate, PSC device based on ox-CNOs doped HTL yield high FF and VOC, thus champion PCE of 15.26 %.
The external quantum efficiency (EQE) spectra with different HTLs is shown in Fig.
6b, presenting that the photon response of devices based on CNOs and ox-CNOs modified PEDOT:PSS HTLs are higher than the pristine device ranged from 400 to 800 nm. The calculated JSC from EQE of pristine device, and the devices based on CNOs and ox-CNOs doped PEDOT:PSS HTLs are 17.14, 20.45, and 20.95 mA/cm2, respectively, which is in agreement with the measured JSC. The high EQE originates from the high conductivity of CNOs and ox-CNOs modified PEDOT:PSS HTLs to increase the electron transport efficiency.
To further verify the reliability of the champion device, the stabilized PCE at a bias
around the maximum power point voltage (0.80 V for champion device) is measured, and the curves are plotted in Fig. 6d. A constant photocurrent of 21.20 mA/cm2 and a PCE of 15.08 % in ambient atmosphere were achieved, indicating that this PSC device is stable and reliable. The PCE histograms of the PSCs with Gaussian fitting are displayed in Fig. 6f. It availably verifies the improved PCEs of the CNOs and ox-CNOs HTLs based devices. Besides, most of the fabricated ox-CNOs HTLs based devices (60%) yield a PCE larger than 14 %, exhibiting the reproducibility and universality.

sections.heading: 2.5. Device stability of PSCs based on CNOs and ox-CNOs modified PEDOT:PSS
HTLs in air ambient.
sections.text:
devices were tested without encapsulation, i.e., the devices were exposed directly to the environment without any cover in an ambient environment at 25 °C and with 30-50 % humidity, and the devices performance with different storage time are shown in Fig. 6a. As we all know, the low stability of PSC is mainly attributed to the degradation of perovskite and the corrosion of metal electrode. PEDOT:PSS is generally considered as an unstable transport layer for organic devices due to its hydrophilic and acidic property [74]. The PCE of the devices based on pristine PEDOT:PSS HTL drop to zero after only 5 days, which shows the dramatic corrosion of ITO electrode by acidic PEDOT:PSS. In
contrast, the CNOs and ox-doped PEDOT:PSS devices show higher ambient stability, especially for the device based on ox-CNOs doped PEDOT:PSS that retain 70 % of its innate PCE and 95 % of innate VOC after storing in air ambient for 10 days.
To verify the degradation of the ITO, the sheet resistances of ITO layers are listed
in Table S3. These ITO layers contact with various HTLs for 10 days, and the HTL layers have already removed for measurement. The sheet resistance of ITO based on pristine PEDOT:PSS is 31.6 Ω/sq, and the sheet resistance of ITO layers based on CNOs and ox-CNOs modified PEDOT:PSS are 12.9 and 11.6 Ω/sq, respectively. The worse electrical conductivity of pristine PEDOT:PSS contacted ITO is caused by corrosion of the acidic PEDOT:PSS. We speculate that the primary reason to lose efficacy of the device based on pristine PEDOT:PSS is corrosion of ITO electrodes. But when use the CNOs and ox-CNOs modified PEDOT:PSS as HTLs, the reduced hydrophilic groups
and sulfonic acid groups of these HTLs nearly show no corrosion to ITO electrode. Meanwhile, there are no obvious degradations of the electrical conductivities in these ITO substrates. For further explanation, we measured the XRD patterns of the perovskite layers based on various HTLs (Fig. S3), the samples were exposed to atmospheric conditions for 10 days. New peaks at 12.65 o assigned to the (001) crystal plane of PbI2 are observed in the XRD patterns of every perovskite layers, and there are no significant differences of these. The XRD result shows that the degradation of perovskite is also detect in the devices which based on CNOs and ox-doped PEDOT:PSS HTLs. The decrease of PCEs for that is mainly due to the degradation of perovskite to cause charge trap to reduce the JSC [75, 76]. In a word, the corrosion of ITO electrode is distinctly inhibited by using CNOs and ox-CNOs modified PEDOT:PSS HTLs, resulting in an obvious improvement of device stability in air ambient.

sections.heading: 3. Conclusion
sections.text:
In summary, we successfully demonstrate the planar PSCs with a great
enhancement in performance and stability by introducing a 0-dimensioned CNOs and ox-CNOs modified PEDOT:PSS HTLs. Consequently, the derived PSCs can yield a distinctly enhanced PCE. Especially for the PSCs based on functional ox-CNOs modified PEDOT:PSS HTL show a promising PCE of about 15.26 %, a high FF of 76 % ,good VOC of 0.94 V, and JSC of 21.34 mA/cm 2, outperforming the pristine device with a PCE of 11.07 %.The increased performance of these derived devices could originate from the matched energy levels, high conductivity and well hydrophobicity, leading to efficient charge transfer occurring between the HTL and perovskite layers and providing an optimal condition for perovskite grown on it. Moreover, compared with the pristine device with the sharply degraded PCE, the device based on ox-CNOs modified HTL show the dramatic improvement of stability due to the ox-CNOs dopant can reduce the acidity and hydrophilicity of modified PEDOT:PSS, suppressing the corrosion of ITO by HTL. On the whole, using CNOs and ox-CNOs to modified the PEDOT:PSS for avoiding the defects of pristine one is a simple, economic, and controllable strategy. This
strategy can provide a feasible route to the low-temperature, flexible, large-scale production of HTL for perovskite solar cells.

Dr. Jiang Huang thanks for the financial support of the UESTC Excellent Young Scholar Project, and Yifan Zheng gratefully acknowledges China Scholarship Council for partial support of this work.

Compared with the conventional mesoporous configuration based on high-temperature processed TiO2 electron transporting layer (ETL) [11, 12], PSCs with planar configuration employ many advantages such as minor hysteresis effects [13, 14], low-temperature solution processibility, [15, 16], and the potential for large-scale manufacturing using a continuous deposition technique on flexible substrates[17-19], which draws lots of attention for recent research work.

metadata.abstractText: Poly (3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) polystyrene sulphonate (PEDOT:PSS) is the most widely used hole transporting layer (HTL) in planar perovskite solar cells, which shows excellent optical, electrical properties and good compatibility with low temperature, solution and flexible processing. Nevertheless, the acidic and hygroscopic property of PEDOT:PSS restricts its film conductivity and leads to the degradation of device stability. Herein, for the first time, we introduce the unprecedentedly
